consent:
Thank you for considering participating in this study. This information sheet outlines the purpose of the study and provides a description of your involvement and rights as a participant, if you agree to take part.



1. What is the research about?

We want to know what people think about different ways of getting money to small businesses. During the COVID-19 pandemic, local governments have used different approaches to deciding which businesses get help. We want to know what you think about these different programs. 



2. Do I have to take part?

No, you don't. It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. You do not have to take part if you do not want to. 



3. What will my involvement be?

This survey takes about 5 minutes. You will need to read instructions and answer some multiple choice and rank-order questions. There are 3 open-ended questions where you have to briefly write/explain an answer. 



4. How do I withdraw from the study?

You can withdraw from the study at any point until you have completed the survey, without having to give a reason. If any questions make you feel uncomfortable, you can stop answering. We will not analyze any incomplete responses, so if you stop the survey before the end, your responses will not be included in any analyses or reports.  



5. What will my information be used for?

I will use the survey responses for an academic paper. I may also share my findings in research talks, reports, blog posts, etc. 



6. Will my taking part and my data be kept confidential? Will it be anonymised?

Your data will be anonymised – you do not give your name so your responses can not be matched back to you. The data will be posted on a website where other researchers can analyze it to check my results or test their own hypotheses. Before it is posted, Prolific IDs and IP addresses will be deleted. 



8. Who has reviewed this study?

This study has undergone ethics review in accordance with the LSE Research Ethics Policy and Procedure.



9. Data Protection Privacy Notice

The LSE Research Privacy Policy can be found at: https://info.lse.ac.uk/staff/divisions/Secretarys-Division/Assets/Documents/Information-Records-Management/Privacy-Notice-for-Research-v1.1.pdf



The legal basis used to process your personal data will be "Public Task." The legal basis used to process special category personal data (e.g. data that reveals racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, health, sex life or sexual orientation, genetic or biometric data) will be for scientific and historical research or statistical purposes.

To request a copy of the data held about you please contact: glpd.info.rights@lse.ac.uk



10. What if I have a question or complaint?

If you have any questions regarding this study please contact the researcher, Dr. Heather Kappes, on h.kappes@lse.ac.uk 

If you have any concerns or complaints regarding the conduct of this research, please contact the LSE Research Governance Manager via research.ethics@lse.ac.uk. 



If you are happy to take part in this study, please tick below.

jw_scale_3: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people earn the rewards and punishments they get.
jw_scale_4: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people who meet with misfortune have brought it on themselves.
jw_scale_5: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that people get what they deserve.
jw_scale_6: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I am asked to mark six in response to this statement to show that I'm reading carefully.
jw_scale_7: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I feel that rewards and punishments are fairly given.
jw_scale_8: Please mark the number that shows how much you disagree or agree with each statement. - I basically feel that the world is a fair place.

w_rankfair_1:
The local government is giving grants to small businesses to help with COVID-19. Here's the process they are using:

 

(1) Small businesses applied asking the government for help

(2) The government checked to see if a small business was eligible

(3) Among the eligible small businesses, the agency is considering using one of the following three methods to select which 500 small businesses will get a grant.

 


Please rank-order these three methods, with the best at the top and the worst at the bottom, in terms of how fair they are. Put the method that's the most fair at the top (1) and the method that's the least fair at the bottom (3). - Lottery: The government randomly selects 500 of the eligible businesses that applied to get the money.
w_rankfair_2:
The local government is giving grants to small businesses to help with COVID-19. Here's the process they are using:

 

(1) Small businesses applied asking the government for help

(2) The government checked to see if a small business was eligible

(3) Among the eligible small businesses, the agency is considering using one of the following three methods to select which 500 small businesses will get a grant.

 


Please rank-order these three methods, with the best at the top and the worst at the bottom, in terms of how fair they are. Put the method that's the most fair at the top (1) and the method that's the least fair at the bottom (3). - First-come, first-served: The government gives the money to the first 500 businesses that apply.
w_rankfair_3:
The local government is giving grants to small businesses to help with COVID-19. Here's the process they are using:

 

(1) Small businesses applied asking the government for help

(2) The government checked to see if a small business was eligible

(3) Among the eligible small businesses, the agency is considering using one of the following three methods to select which 500 small businesses will get a grant.

 


Please rank-order these three methods, with the best at the top and the worst at the bottom, in terms of how fair they are. Put the method that's the most fair at the top (1) and the method that's the least fair at the bottom (3). - Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

pf_fr_1: You think a points system is the most fair way for the government to select which businesses to help. Why do you think a points system is MORE fair than first-come, first-served and a lottery?
pf_fr_2: And you think first-come, first-served is more fair than a lottery. Why do you think a lottery is least fair?
pf_time:
Some of the methods that local governments used were faster at getting money to businesses. Faster was better, because businesses needed the money to pay bills and stay open.
 

Imagine that you learn that the method you think is most fair---a points system---means businesses must wait longer to get money than if the government uses first-come, first-served. How much extra time do you think it's okay to make businesses wait?
pl_fr_1: You think a points system is the most fair way for the government to select which businesses to help. Why do you think a points system is MORE fair than a lottery and first-come, first-served?
pl_fr_2: And you think a lottery is more fair than first-come first-served. Why do you think first-come first-served is least fair?

Q37: The researcher definitely wanted me to say first-come first-served was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
fp_fr_1: I think the first-come, first-served approach is probably fairest because it provides a method for motivated respondents to obtain the help they want regardless of the details of their business. This standard can undermine fairness (a large company with no need for the help can still get it), but it at least allows everyone to take the initiative and act according to their need. It seems plausible that those most motivated to act will generally be those most in need. The points system prioritizes need directly but also undermines that action by adding other criteria that may lead to neglect of many companies in need.
fp_fr_2: A lottery is least fair because while it gives everyone an equal chance of being selected for aid and thus is completely fair in one sense, that sense is completely context-blind. The lottery approach calls to mind the adage "The law in its majesty forbids rich and poor alike from sleeping under bridges." A program like this is established in the first place because an unusual state of deprivation has arisen in the commercial sector with particular features whose details, including differential distribution of need, ought to be considered in decision-making.
fp_time: Use first-come first-served even if it takes 2 weeks longer to get money to businesses than a points system
legup_w: I'm not sure if they should receive an advantage

Q37: I don't think the researcher cared which method I said was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by minorities. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
lf_fr_1: First-come, first-served may not necessarily be fair, because organizations that are quickest may have some inherent advantages in terms of size or manpower that enables them to apply faster. A points system is inherently unfair in a couple of ways. I actually think that giving businesses that are the worst-off is a good idea, but then adding some sort of gender requirement is ridiculous. If a business is owned by a husband/wife, for example, the points system would favor the one with the wife listed as owner when the two businesses could be identical in every other respect. Such a simplistic system fails to recognize a lot of the nuance in small business.
lf_fr_2: I'll repeat my previous answer in that ignoring other aspects of the business for the sake of gender misses a lot of the nuance and complexity of small business ownership. If a business is owned by a husband/wife, for example, the points system would favor the one with the wife listed as owner when the two businesses could be identical in every other respect. Such a simplistic system fails to recognize a lot of the nuance in small business.

Q37: The researcher might have wanted me to say points was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pl_fr_1: The point system took into account the level of COVID-19 damage which, in most cases, should roughly translate to the amount of need. There were two ways to look at fairness in the question. The first being free from any sort of discrimination. In this scenario, the lottery would have been the first choice because it is completely random. I chose to look at it from the other perspective where fair means without unjust advantage. The point system took into account the disadvantages that a business might already be dealing with and sort of helped level the playing field.
pl_fr_2: A first-come, first-served system might be the most unfair because it seems that people who heard about the programs first or had professionals file their paperwork would be the most likely to get their applications in first. These people would most likely be people who don't have as much need as someone who struggled to file paperwork on their own. Even if this assessment is completely off-base the first-come, first-served system does not take any other factors into account (need, type of business, community, etc). A lottery was my middle selection because it is completely random so I would expect a more fair distribution of help between businesses with more need and those with less.
pl_time: Use a points system even if it takes 2 weeks longer to get money to businesses than a lottery
legup_w: I'm not sure if they should receive an advantage

In reality, going by damage done to the business would be the fairest way, but the one with that criteria also had more points awarded if the business was owned by a women. This, in my mind is discriminatory because there could be a male owned business that really needs the money, but the money could instead go to a female owned business that has suffered less losses simply because they are headed by a female. I think that the best way to do it is to simply look at the losses and the need and make determinations based on that. Then, they can look to make sure that women are being properly represented and perhaps give the funds to a female owned business in some cases when the funds are close in order to distribute things fairly. IE, try to make it fifty fifty if possible.
lf_fr_2: I think it is the least fair because it takes the sex of the owner into account, opening up the possibility of businesses with more need not getting funding over a business with less need simply because they are not headed by a women. Additionally, the amount of points gained for the business being headed by a women and its overall impact is not discussed so there are to many unknowns there.

pf_fr_1: A points-based system represents the most equitable method of funds allotment in this case, as this method assesses true merit and need over the other methods described, in particularly the lottery and first-come, first- served methods. Q37: I don't think the researcher cared which method I said was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pl_fr_1: A points system allows the government to identify who to give support to first based on important factors that a business does or does not meet. This targeted aid means that businesses that provide unique importance to the local economy like women or people of color-owned businesses receive the aid they need to stay afloat, which ensures small businesses can remain diverse instead of white, male-dominated. A lottery system is fair in its complete randomness, but that means there's more potential for less diverse businesses to receive the aid over more diverse.
pl_fr_2: First-come first-serve systems can be unfair because they allow those who have the resources and ability to apply quicker than others to benefit first. Smaller businesses who don't have the ability to apply first or run into issues, later on, are more likely to be left out in the cold in regards to support than larger businesses. A lottery is more fair because it's completely randomized.
pl_time: Use a points system even if it takes 2 weeks longer to get money to businesses than a lottery
legup_w: Yes they should receive an advantage
Q37: I don't think the researcher cared which method I said was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pl_fr_1: Without taking into account the things points are being given for: longevity of business, how much COVID has damaged the business, and how much society has damaged or worked against the business prior to COVID, we might end up giving money to businesses that are in great shape rather than to businesses that are hurting -- or giving it to fly-by-night shops that opened last week for the purpose of collecting assistance money.
pl_fr_2: Lotteries at least are a flat system where everyone, regardless of need, has the same chance.  First-come first-served, in this kind of situation, ends up rewarding businesses which can fill out complicated government paperwork the quickest: those with high-intelligence and/or high-education owners and staff, or those who can afford to hire a lawyer or accountant to do this work swiftly for them -- that is, the very companies *least* in need of help.
pl_time: Use a points system even if it takes 2 weeks longer to get money to businesses than a lottery
m_outcomes: It's still a crap-shoot because we don't know whether there are lots of more-damaged businesses they're competing against for the money, but they'd definitely do better than with a lottery.  Since you said minority-owned businesses do poorly and are hard to set up and get loans for, that implies that white-owned businesses are more common numerically, meaning a lottery choosing among businesses randomly will favor whites simply because they're a majority of businesses.

This is due to my previous experience in the corporate world - we were required to spend a portion of our gov't contract on Small Disadvantaged Businesses -which included women-owned businesses. What I learned firsthand was that none of the businesses we gave money to under that program were actually women-owned. These men had their mother (usually) as owner of their business - two brothers even were in the local paper in a story touting how they built up their business- nowhere did it mention that on paper it was their mother's business and when I talked to one of the brothers about work, I mentioned that story and he laughed when I asked "isn't it your Mom's business?' - Then I went through our list of women owned businesses and called and asked to talk to the owner - everytime I was put through to a man and no woman was available to even act like the owner. Its a sham and a scam because actual businesses owned by women are not given an advantage by the programs that are supposed to help them.

pl_fr_1: A lottery or first come, first served does not necessarily allocate funds to the businesses that need it most.  The points system is the most fair because it takes a more holistic approach to the survival and challenges of a particular business (I.e. minority-businesses experienced barriers to entry even prior to the pandemic, so they need more help).

m_outcomes: I think the minority-owned businesses would be able to ride the worst part of the pandemic using these funds, supplemented by strong community support, to make it through the pandemic.

Q37: I don't think the researcher cared which method I said was the most fair.
first_choice: First-come, first-served: The government gives the money to the first 500 businesses that apply.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pl_fr_1: Implementing a points system is a way to increase the likelihood that monies invested will go to businesses responsible with their finances and have a better chance to weather the pandemic. At least with a lottery, some of the most deserving recipients have a chance apart from being cherry-picked by the selection committee. First-come, first-served can easily be arranged in advance, thus excluding some more appropriately deserving businesses.
pl_fr_2: Many multi-million (if not multi-billion) dollar businesses who could better survive a financial setback were first to submit requests for funding. Many received millions of dollars in pandemic relief while many local businesses did, are, and will go under because they did not have access to holdover funding. It was not a fair playing field for those who needed it.
pl_time: Use a points system even if takes 2 months longer to get money to businesses than a lottery
m_outcomes: Minority-owned businesses would fair about as well as non-minority owned businesses. Since it is harder for minorities to get loans for businesses than non-minority business owners, and minority businesses are not likely to have been around as long as non-minority businesses because they get fewer bank loans, it would stand that more minority businesses would have a chance to break even.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pf_fr_1: Using a points based process is likely to identify the companies most in need and/or those that will support he greatest number of jobs. A points system will also compel the company owners to carefully consider if they qualify and can use the grants as intended. Organizations that do not need the funds and do not qualify are less likely to apply, leaving money for more deserving applicants.
pf_fr_2: There tends to be little scrutiny over the qualifications if a lottery is introduced. In a first-come, first-served scenario the applicants are more likely required to produce proof of need and can be vetted.
pf_time: Only use a points system if it gets money to businesses as quickly as first-come first-served
m_outcomes: Minority-owned should fare well under a points-based system. They  tend to be concentrated in the service sector that has been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

Q45: The reason I chose I don't know if women owned business should get an advantage for receiving funds is that that privilege can be abused by people it's not intended for.  Say a woman owned company gets a contract simply for that reason of being a woman owned business.  You may see a lot of partnering up of companies purely for the sake of getting the contract.  Example, a woman might not be interested in a business or contract at at all.  The contract male owned company knows about the contract, how lucrative it is, but can't get it because it's mandated for a woman company.  That may lead to them partnering up so that the woman owned company will get the contract, but the man owned company will be responsible for servicing it.  So in that case, should the woman owned company be really giving an advantage?  I would verbalize this better as writing it may seem kind of harsh, but I've seen it.

first_choice: Lottery: The government randomly selects 500 of the eligible businesses that applied to get the money.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
pl_fr_1: A points system provides a direct measure of stated concerns to assess community impact and positively influence stability and sustainability among small businesses in need of assistance.  It implies accountability on all sides, and may be transparent.
pl_fr_2: Many very large businesses owned by wealthy and powerful individuals and interests applied for and got small business relief early on in the pandemic, arguably diminishing the benefit otherwise available to genuine challenged small businesses for whom the program was ostensibly intended.  First come first serve may well favor businesses who have the resources, legal teams, and advantages that reflect existing systemic inequity, while smaller businesses most affected by the pandemic and vulnerable due to their disadvantage would continue to suffer disproportionately.  However, one might assume that the majority of businesses applying for assistance do have a legitimate claim, such as they are determined to be eligible, so a lottery system would allow for assistance to be granted in a more impartial way that could yet provide for asymmetrical circumstances or particularities of need.
pl_time: Use a points system even if it takes 2 weeks longer to get money to businesses than a lottery
m_outcomes: I think that they would stand to gain based on the first and last conditions, but might still be disadvantaged in the consideration of the length of time they have been around.  That is the aspect that concerns me most, as again systemic inequities might equally be expressed, and it could stifle younger more progressive ventures that represent contemporary minority and also immigrant owned business interests.

Q37: The researcher might have wanted me to say lottery was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by minorities. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
fl_fr_1: I think a first-come first served approach is as fair as the lottery approach - not more fair.  Both approaches have a fair amount of randomness associated with them in that the first-come approach depends on how the message is communicated out that the support is available and how it can be accessed.  Nothing has been said about what the limits are on what it means to be a small business in order to qualify for the funding so I can't rate these approaches on that factor.
fl_fr_2: Any government-designed system of points brings with it pre-conceived notions of "value" - what should be assessed for points and how many points should be assigned based on the assessment. The initial decision on what to assess screams out bias, the assessment process screams out bias, and the final point scoring screams out bias.  I suspect the point system would be the most flawed and most political of all the schemes.
fl_time: Only use first-come first-served if it gets money to businesses as quickly as a lottery
m_outcomes: I have no idea - that would depend on how well the government does at communicating the plan and the process for the application for aid.

lf_fr_1: Because it does not rely on human judgement, nor on their possible biases.
lf_fr_2: First come, first serve is, again, a way to avoid human bias. A points system is open to those biases, insofar as someone has to decide what the points are given for, and the allotting and tallying of the points is open to human preference and tampering. A human would also have to decide what constitutes "more damage" for a business. It's also biased against younger businesses, and businesses not owned by women.
lf_time: Only use a lottery if it gets money to businesses as quickly as first-come first-served

Q37: I don't think the researcher cared which method I said was the most fair.
first_choice: Points-based system: The government assigns more points to businesses that applied if they have more COVID-19 damage, have been around for longer, and if they are owned by women. The 500 businesses with the most points get funded.

consent: I have read this information and I agree to take part in this study.
lf_fr_1: First come, first served relies on factors outside the applicant's control. Suppose someone more deserving receives info about the funds, the application process, and the deadline later than someone who already has a million dollars in the bank? Suppose this person *does* mail the application early, but due to the vagaries of the postal delivery system, his application is received after the millionaire's application, or past the deadline, or lost in the system altogether.
lf_fr_2: A points system relies on dubious statistics about who is more disadvantaged and why, and the points are set and allocated by politicians who have their own biases. Race should absolutely not enter into the equation. Undesirable as first-come, first-served may be, it is much to be preferred over any points system.
lf_time: Use a lottery even if takes 2 months longer to get money to businesses than first-come first-served
m_outcomes: Using that method, the funds would most likely be equitably distributed among the various races according to the percentage of the applicants they represent. A blind lottery is far more likely than either of the other two methods to assure this outcome.

fl_fr_2: I don't think a points system is far insofar as it gives preference to minority owned businesses. Mine may not be a popular opinion, but I don't believe in giving preference because of race or minority status. I DO believe in treating EVERYONE fairly, and helping ALL struggling people. I think the country is moving toward a bias against whites, giving statistics about the median and the average white family being wealthier than other groups. However, no one mentions that the ultra rich (many of whom, yes, are white) are skewing these averages upward. There are plenty of poor and struggling white families and they should not be disregarded because they belong to the "wealthier race". I am in favor of helping people on the basis of need, and helping all those who need help, not prioritizing one person over another because of heritage and genetics, over which they had no control.
